title: How to Perform the Adhan (with Du'a and Iqama)

steps.title: Call the adhan before each of the 5 daily prayers.
steps.content: Call the adhan before each of the 5 daily prayers. These prayers are the Fajr (before sunrise), Dhuhr (at noon), Asr (between noon and sunset), Maghreb (just after sunset), and Isha (before midnight). Your community will take more or less time to congregate based on its size, so consult your spiritual leaders to find out how long in advance you should perform the call. Specific times for each prayer varies by location, so use a tool like IslamicFinder to find the specific times for your location.

steps.title: Wash your hands, face, arms, and feet to prepare for prayer.
steps.content: Wash your hands, face, arms, and feet to prepare for prayer. Before you pray, perform wudu to purify yourself—the adhan isn’t just a call to prayer, it’s a prayer itself. If you neglect to wash yourself earnestly and reverently, your prayer may not be accepted by Allah. Make your intention (niyyah) before you begin, resolving to wash and pray as best you can. [1] X Research source Gargle water in your mouth three times to remove remaining food. Inhale water into your nose to clear your breathing passages. Wash your face 3 times: use your hand to spread water from your right ear to your left ear, and then from your hairline down to your chin. Thoroughly wash your feet and your forearms – 3 times each. Clean your head and wash out your ears. Bear in mind that you must repeat wudu if you nullify it. Any form of body discharge (urination, defecation, gas, bleeding) invalidates wudu, as does a bout of deep sleep.

steps.title: Stand facing the Qibla.
steps.content: Stand facing the Qibla. The Qibla is the direction of the Kaaba in Mecca. All Muslims face this place when they pray during salah, and many mu'adhins face the Qibla when calling the adhan. [2] X Research source If possible, stand in a high place, like a tower, a rooftop, or an upstairs window.

steps.title: Set your intention (or niyyah) to call the adhan, and cover your ears.
steps.content: Set your intention (or niyyah ) to call the adhan, and cover your ears. Just as you wash yourself before the adhan, you also set your intention beforehand. [3] X Research source Take a few moments to consider what this moment means to you, to your faith, and to the people who you are calling. Muffle your ears with your palms or index fingers index fingers. Muffling is optional, but traditional. [4] X Research source Plugging your ears may help you set your intention and focus on the words you are about to say.

steps.title: Begin by calling Allahu Akbar (ٱللهُ أَكْبَر) 4 times.
steps.content: Begin by calling Allahu Akbar (ٱللهُ أَكْبَر) 4 times. This means "Allah is the greatest". Group the repetition into 2 sets of 2: " Allahu Akbar; Allahu Akbar. Allahu Akbar; Allahu Akbar! " [5] X Research source Say it slowly, in a loud and clear voice. Consider singing the words, if you feel comfortable doing so. After you recite each sentence, the rest of the congregation ( jama'ah ) will softly answer every phrase that the mu'adhdhin recites – with one exception. After "hayya 'alasalah" and "hayya 'alal falah," the others should answer with La hawla wala kuwata ila billah , meaning "There is no Power or Authority except Allah." Followers of the Maliki Madhab say this line twice instead of 4 times.

steps.title: Say Ashhadu ala ilaha illallah (أشهد أن لا إله إلا الله) twice.
steps.content: Say Ashhadu ala ilaha illallah ( أشهد أن لا إله إلا الله ) twice. This means "I testify that there is no god but Allah." Pronounce it "ash-hadu ala i-laa-ha ill-all-ah." [6] X Research source

steps.title: Repeat Ash hadu anna Muhammadar rasoolullah (أشهد أن محمد رسول الله) twice.
steps.content: Repeat Ash hadu anna Muhammadar rasoolullah ( أشهد أن محمد رسول الله ) twice. This means "I testify that Muhammad is the Messenger of God." Pronounce it "ash-hadu ana Mu-ha-mud-ar rah-sool all-ah". [7] X Research source Pace yourself, and avoid rushing through the words.

steps.title: Call Hayya 'ala as-salah (حي على الصلاة) twice.
steps.content: Call Hayya 'ala as-salah ( حي على الصلاة ) twice. This means, "Come to prayer." Pronounce it "hey-ah-'alas sal-ah". [8] X Research source

steps.title: Say Hayya 'ala al-falah (حي على الفلاح) twice.
steps.content: Say Hayya 'ala al-falah ( حي على الفلاح ) twice. It translates to "Come to success." Pronounce it "hey-ah-alal -fa-lah". [9] X Research source

steps.title: Say a sect-specific line if you are Sunni or Shia.
steps.content: Say a sect-specific line if you are Sunni or Shia. There is some disagreement about what comes after "Hayya'ala al-falah" and before the final repetitions of "Allahu Akbar". Sunnis and Shias have their own specific lines, but most schools omit these. If you aren't sure what to do, consider skipping this line and moving on to the next phrase. [10] X Research source If you are a Sunni , say "Assalatu khayru min an-naum" here. This means "Prayer is better than sleep." Only use this line when calling Fajr, the dawn prayer. If you are a Shia , say "Hayya- al Khair al amal." This encourages worshipers to "Hasten toward the best thing."

steps.title: Repeat "Allahu Akbar" (الله أكبر) twice, followed by "La ilaha illallah" (لا إله إلا الله).
steps.content: Repeat " Allahu Akbar " ( الله أكبر ) twice, followed by "La ilaha illallah" ( لا إله إلا الله ). This last line translates to, "There is none worthy of worship except God." Most mu'adhdhins only say this once, according to the 4 schools, although the Imamis say it twice. The Malikis and Shafi’is permit repetition of the last line, considering it sunnah: the adhan, according to them, is not invalid if it is recited only once, as the Imamis hold. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Recite a du’a to yourself after the adhan.
steps.content: Recite a du’a to yourself after the adhan . A du'a is a personal prayer or meditation, said in a lower voice than the adhan. Say, " Allahumma Rabba Hathihil Da'awatiTaamma WaSalatil-qaa’ima, Aati Sayyedana Muhammada nil-Waseelata Wal-Fadeelata Wal-Darajatal-'aleyata Al Rafî‘a, Wab‘ath-hu Maqaman Mahmudanilathee Wa‘adtahu, Innaka La Tukhliful-Mee'ad. " [12] X Research source This translates to, “O Allah! Lord of this perfect call (perfect by not ascribing partners to You) and of the regular prayer which is going to be established, give Muhammad the right of intercession and illustriousness, and resurrect him to the best and the highest place in Paradise that You promised him, then my intercession for him will be allowed on the Day of Resurrection.” You do not need to fill this space with a du'a, but it is mustahabb (preferred) to do so.

steps.title: Recite the iqama
steps.content: Recite the iqama once the community has assembled. This is the second call to prayer before the beginning of salah once everyone has gathered, and is more or less a repeat of the adhan. The exact words and their repetitions will vary from school to school, so consider asking a respected member of your community about exactly what to say. Once you say the iqama , the prayer session can begin. [13] X Research source Say the iqama with a lower voice than you called the adhan , but so that those in the prayer space can still hear you. Recite the iqama quicker, as the prayer is going to start straight after you finish. The difference between iqamah and adhan is that during iqamah , after saying haya 'alal falaah , you say qad qaama tis-salaah (the prayer has begun). Some people say this once, others say this twice. This depends on the school of jurisprudence ( madhab ) followed. Saying it twice is sunnah according to a saheeh hadith. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Follow the prayer with the congregation.
steps.content: Follow the prayer with the congregation. Join your community in the salah , following your imam or prayer leader in the recitation. Reflect on your role in calling the adhan, and set your intention now on the prayer at hand. [15] X Research source
